name: World Explorer
description: Our most popular course connects students to learn about life, history, and cultures around the world. • Course begins February 6th • 6 Weeks • 30 mins per week • Ages 9 and up
announcement: Explore global cultures with PenPals from around the world
body_three:
Course Timeline


This collaborative course begins every two weeks. Enroll your class and invite your students before Feb 5 to join the next exchange!


Today - Feb 5: Students join your class by signing up at go.penpalschools.com using the unique class code that we provide in your teacher dashboard.


Feb 5: Each student is matched with up to 3 PenPals from 3 different classrooms around the world. Students are matched based on age, geography, and many other attributes!


Feb 6 - Mar 12: Students complete weekly lessons with their PenPals. Collaboration is asynchronous so students can log in at any time during the week. See the syllabus below or demo the course.


Mar 13 - Mar 17: Students collaborate with their PenPals on a reflective project to demonstrate what they’ve learned.


Students Will Learn


World Knowledge: Global Awareness and Empathy

Reading Skills

Writing Skills

Technology Skills

Collaboration Skills


Course Includes


  • Original Videos

  • Weekly Articles

  • Photos

  • Vocabulary Charts

  • Printable Classroom Activities

  • Grading Rubrics for Teachers

  • Completion Certificate



Syllabus



Essential Question


In what ways are communities around the world more similar or more different than we expect?



Week 1: Daily Life


Students start the World Explorer course learning about daily life around the world. Through an emphasis on the similarities and differences between urban and rural communities, students discuss family, school, and all the little things that make life interesting. Students learn about geography, religion, transportation, and have the opportunity to discuss these topic with their PenPals.


Sample Discussion Question: What do communities look like where your PenPals live? Compare your PenPals’ communities with your community. How are they similar and different?


Week 2: Food


In Week 2, students explore and compare food and eating habits around the world. Students discuss the foods that are grown or manufactured in their communities, common ingredients, and national dishes. PenPals will also learn about the impact of globalization on what and how people eat.


Sample Discussion Question:  How do international influences impact what people eat where your PenPals live?



Week 3: History


Week 3 is all about the past. During this unit, students learn about ancient civilizations, significant inventions, and influential people from around the world. Students will discover important events that shaped the world where their PenPals live today.


Sample Discussion Question: What was an important event in the history of your  community? What effects from that event are still visible today?



Week 4: Art and Literature


In Week 4, students study art from communities around the world. Not only will students learn about the visual arts like painting, sculpture, and fashion, but students will also learn about music, and literature. The Art and Literature unit gives students the opportunity to build on what they learn in Week 3 and think about how art represents their culture and community.


Sample Discussion Question: In what different ways does art reflect your culture? Give specific example



Week 5: Popular Culture


PenPals love talking about popular culture! This week is entirely dedicated to the sports, celebrities, movies, and television shows that your students love. After learning about popular activities and famous people, PenPals have the chance to compare and contrast the things that appeal to young people all around the world.


Sample Discussion Question: Explain how technology and international influences impact pop culture around the world.



Week 6: Reflection


In the final week of World Explorer, students discuss what they learned during the course before saying goodbye to their PenPals. Not ready for the learning fun to end? Your students can always sign-up to take a new course!


Sample Discussion Question: How has your opinion of the part of the world where your PenPals lives changed? Are people more similar or different than you expected?


Classroom Project


Build a classroom atlas! Each week students should work to report and share with the class and school community what they are learning about their PenPals and their PenPals’ regions of the world. The atlas might include maps, recipes, profiles of historical figures, art, music, and literature, and examples from popular culture.




Reviews


“Over 120 of my 6th grade world geography students enrolled and completed the Intermediate World Explorer course. The highlight for the students each week was looking forward to the personal communication they received from their PenPal.”  -Erica, New Jersey


“Most of all they loved the videos and exchanging messages with PenPals. The World Explorer course integrates perfectly well with the national Ukrainian curriculum.” -Hannah, Ukraine


“Just as I love seeing students' fascination when they encounter new traditions and customs of different cultures, I love seeing students experience the fascination that comes from realizing that kids from other cultures and other parts of the world really aren't so different from them.” -Lynn, Texas

name: The World Through My Eyes
description: Students connect to explore stories from around the world told by five young documentary filmmakers. • Course begins February 6th • 6 Weeks • 45 mins per week • Ages 12 and up
announcement: Learn about global issues with PenPals from around the world
body_three:
Course Timeline


This collaborative course begins every two weeks. Enroll your class and invite your students before Feb 5 to join the next exchange!


Today - Feb 5: Students join your class by signing up at go.penpalschools.com using the unique class code that we provide in your teacher dashboard.


Feb 5: Each student is matched with up to 3 PenPals from 3 different classrooms around the world. Students are matched based on age, geography, and many other attributes!


Feb 6 - Mar 12: Students complete weekly lessons with their PenPals. Collaboration is asynchronous so students can log in at any time during the week. See the syllabus below or demo the course.


Mar 13- Mar 17: Students collaborate with their PenPals on a reflective project to demonstrate what they’ve learned.


Students Will Learn


World Knowledge: Global Awareness and Empathy, Human Rights Issues, and Global Conflict

Reading Skills

Writing Skills, Elements of Filmmaking and Storytelling

Technology Skills

Collaboration Skills


Course Includes


  • Original Videos

  • Weekly Articles

  • Photos

  • Maps

  • National Statistics

  • Vocabulary Charts

  • Printable Classroom Activities

  • Grading Rubrics for Teachers

  • Completion Certificate

Syllabus


Week 1: Home Is Where You Find It


Students begin this course learning the story of Alcides Soares, a young boy in Mozambique, Africa who is on a journey to find his brother and create a new sense of family. Students learn about poverty, family, and how diseases like HIV/AIDS can affect a community.


Sample Discussion Question: Why do you think Alcides chose to share his story with people around the world?



Week 2: My Country is Tibet


During the second week of The World Through My Eyes, students learn about Namgyal Wangchuk Trichen Lhagyari, the teenage king of Tibet. As Students work with their PenPals, they learn about the importance of family history, the plight of refugees around the world, the conflict between China and Tibet.


Sample Discussion Question: How did Trichen and his family become refugees? What are other reasons that people might become refugees?



Week 3: Displaced But Not Defeated


This week, students learn about María Ceballos Paz, a teenager in Colombia. María has been living in displacement for the past nine years as a result of Colombia's civil war. Students learn about the nation of Colombia and the effects civil war and armed conflict can have on a community.


Sample Discussion Question: The displaced people who live in Cali are victims of discrimination. What can a community do to welcome people displaced by violence?



Week 4: Fire In Our Hearts


Fire in Our Hearts is a short film made by Jayshree Janu Kharpade, a sixteen-year-old girl from the Warli tribe in the Maharashtra State, India. Jayshree shares her journey as she advances from illiterate laborer, to scholar and young activist. Students learn about the importance of education and more than 60 million school-age girls around the world who do not have the opportunity to attend school.


Sample Discussion Question: Why do you think that everyone should have access to a high-quality education?



Week 5: Poet Against Prejudice


Week 5 introduces students to Faiza Almontaser, a 17-year old immigrant from New York City. Despite losing close friends to violence and facing discrimination at school, Faiza and her family continue to embrace their new life in the United States. Students learn about the struggles faced by immigrant communities and the power of art as a way to express oneself.


Sample Discussion Question: What can people from different groups do to show tolerance? How might more tolerance improve your school’s culture?



Week 6: The World Though Our Eyes


In the final week of this course, Students and their PenPals work together to make a plan of action. After discussing the five BYKids films, students will choose a cause or a film to share with their community. Students learn how they can be agents of change for people living in crisis in communities around the world.


Sample Discussion Question: Which BYkids film would you want to share with your community? Why did you choose this film?


Reviews


“My experience using PenPal Schools was great! . My students were enthusiastic about sharing and knowing.  They became critics when information provided was not enough and motivated to search for more.” -Patricia, Argentina


“BYKids films are fascinating for me and my students. They offer a perspective that my American students rarely see -- that of a child in another part of the world.” -John, North Carolina

name: American Perspectives
description: Students connect to study and share perspectives on issues at the center of the US political debate. • Course begins February 6th • 6 Weeks • 30 mins per week • Ages 9 and up
announcement: Explore issues at the center of the US political debate with PenPals
body_three:
Course Timeline


This collaborative course begins every two weeks. Enroll your class and invite your students before Feb 5 to join the next exchange!


Today - Feb 5: Students join your class by signing up at go.penpalschools.com using the unique class code that we provide in your teacher dashboard.


Feb 5: Each student is matched with up to 3 PenPals from 3 different classrooms around the world. Students are matched based on age, geography, and many other attributes!


Feb 6 - Mar 12: Students complete weekly lessons with their PenPals. Collaboration is asynchronous so students can log in at any time during the week. See the syllabus below or demo the course.


Mar 13 - Mar 17: Students collaborate with their PenPals on a reflective project to demonstrate what they’ve learned.


Students Will Learn


US Political Issues & American Civics

Reading Skills

Writing Skills

Technology Skills

Collaboration Skills


Course Includes


  • Original Videos

  • Weekly Articles

  • Photos

  • Infographics

  • National Statistics

  • Vocabulary Charts

  • Printable Classroom Activities

  • Grading Rubrics for Teachers

  • Course Completion Certification

Syllabus


Week 1: Education


Week 1 explores Education in the United States. Students first learn about the history of the public education system before learning about policies and positions designed to impact public education.


Sample Discussion Question: Do you think standardized testing can help the government improve schools?



Week 2: The Economy


The Economy consistently ranks as the most important issue among US voters. This week, students explore topics like unemployment and job creation. They then learn about changing US based industries and how communities adapt as jobs change.


Sample Discussion Question: The unemployment rate can indicate how well the economy is doing. What changes would you recommend to improve the unemployment rate?



Week 3: Immigration


More immigrants are coming to the United States than at any other point in the country’s history. During Week 3, students learn about the history of immigrant communities in the United States, the difference between legal and illegal immigrants, the process of immigrating to the United States, and the effects of immigrants on the US economy.


Sample Discussion Question: How have immigrants impacted American culture?



Week 4: Energy and the Environment


Many students might not think about the energy they use, but energy is an important part of our daily lives. In Week 4, students learn how people across the United States use and produce energy. Students learn about the difference between fossil and renewable fuel sources, and the effects each fuel source has on the environment.


Sample Discussion Question: Do you think the United States should spend time and money drilling for oil and fracking for natural gas, or should the government spend resources on clean energy like wind and solar? Why?



Week 5: Health Care


During Week 5, students study the US health care system. Students learn about health care, health insurance, and factors that make a health care system expensive. Students compare the US health care system with other countries around the world before learning about current solutions proposed by members of the US government.


Sample Discussion Question: What responsibilities do you think the United States government has to make sure that citizens can access affordable health care?



Week 6: Rock the Vote!


In the final week of American Perspectives, students learn about the election process. Students learn about voting requirements, the types of legislature that appears on federal, state, and municipal ballots, and what positions are held by elected officials.


Sample Discussion Question: What political issue is most important to you? How can you bring awareness to this issue and make your voice heard at the local, state, or federal level?


Reviews


“This PenPal Schools course had a very simple way of laying out the pros and the cons of each issue!” -Margaret, New York

name: Protecting the Planet
description: Students from around the world connect to explore environmental issues and the inspiring people working to address them. • Course begins February 6th • 30 mins per week • Ages 9 and up
announcement: Learn about environmental challenges and solutions with PenPals from around the world
body_three:
Course Timeline


This collaborative course begins every two weeks. Enroll your class and invite your students before Feb 5 to join the next exchange!


Today - Feb 5: Students join your class by signing up at go.penpalschools.com using the unique class code that we provide in your teacher dashboard.


Feb 5: Each student is matched with up to 3 PenPals from 3 different classrooms around the world. Students are matched based on age, geography, and many other attributes!


Feb 6 - Mar 12: Students complete weekly lessons with their PenPals. Collaboration is asynchronous so students can log in at any time during the week. See the syllabus below or demo the course.


Mar 13 - Mar 17: Students collaborate with their PenPals on a reflective project to demonstrate what they’ve learned.


Students Will Learn


World Knowledge: An understanding of environmental issues and conservation efforts

Reading Skills

Writing Skills

Technology Skills

Collaboration Skills


Course Includes


  • Original Videos

  • Weekly Articles

  • Photos

  • Vocabulary Charts

  • Printable Classroom Activities

  • Grading Rubrics for Teachers

  • Completion Certificate


Syllabus


Essential Question


Are individuals, community organizations, and governments responsible for protecting the environment? If so, are they doing enough to ensure that the next generation has a healthy planet?



Week 1: A Pollinator Problem


Bees, butterflies, and other pollinators are in danger of going extinct. Yet, as this article shows, there are steps we can take to protect these pollinators and the important contributions they make to producing the foods we eat. This week, students work with their PenPals to explore the impact of agricultural production on pollinators. Students learn about the decline of pollinators and explore possible solutions to this problem.


Sample Discussion Question: What are some reasons that people would want to protect the environment?



Week 2: The Great Barrier Reef is Under Attack


The Great Barrier Reef is dying, and scientists say protecting it will require a global solution. In Week 2, students read an article about the bleaching of coral reefs. Students will work with their PenPals to understand the causes of climate change, the effects of bleaching, and possible solutions to these problems.


Sample Discussion Question: What would it take to persuade more people to care about coral reefs? Explain.



Week 3: A Groundbreaking Crisis


In Week 3, students learn about the rise of earthquakes in Oklahoma. They will explore whether Oklahoma’s earthquakes can be traced to the rise of the fossil fuel industry and oil drilling across the state. As students work with their PenPals to explore the impact of oil production on the environment, they will consider how technology and industry impact the environment and whether these innovations are worth the cost.


Sample Discussion Question: Do you think that the benefits of using fossil fuels are worth the potential drawbacks?



Week 4: Saving Rhinos


This week, students and their PenPals read about the Black Mambas, an all-woman anti-poaching unit that protects rhinos in South Africa’s Balule Nature Reserve. Students will consider the role individuals have in protecting the environment and which strategies are most effective.


Sample Discussion Question: Why do you think the Black Mamba scouts have had success stopping poachers?



Week 5: Under the Sea


In week Week 5, students read an article profiling Sylvia Earle and her mission to protect the world’s oceans. Students and their PenPals learn how one person can promote conservation efforts that have a positive impact all around the world. Students explore the strategies Earle uses to promote ocean conservation and the effect of her efforts.


Sample Discussion Question: Why do you think Sylvia Earle is recruiting young people to help with her conservation efforts?



Week 6: Kid Heroes for the Planet


In the final week of the course, students and their PenPals will read about young people from around the world who are drawing attention to environmental issues. After reading about these inspiring individuals, students will work with their classmates and PenPals to take action and encourage members of their own community to support a worthwhile cause.


Sample Discussion Question: How can you, your PenPal, and your classmates inspire others to address an issue impacting the environment?

name: Walking to Freedom
description: Students from around the world connect to study civic leaders who advocate for acceptance and equality. • Course begins February 6th • 6 Weeks • 30 mins per week • Ages 9 and up
announcement: Learn about the history of civil rights with PenPals from around the world
body_three:
Course Timeline


This collaborative course begins every two weeks. Enroll your class and invite your students before Feb 5 to join the next exchange!


Today - Feb 5: Students join your class by signing up at go.penpalschools.com using the unique class code that we provide in your teacher dashboard.


Feb 5: Each student is matched with up to 3 PenPals from 3 different classrooms around the world. Students are matched based on age, geography, and many other attributes!


Feb 6 - Mar 12: Students complete weekly lessons with their PenPals. Collaboration is asynchronous so students can log in at any time during the week. See the syllabus below or demo the course.


Mar 13 - Mar 17: Students collaborate with their PenPals on a reflective project to demonstrate what they’ve learned.


Students Will Learn


World Knowledge: Global Awareness, The History of Segregation and Discrimination, and Activists Who Fought for Equality and Acceptance

Reading Skills

Writing Skills

Technology Skills

Collaboration Skills


Course Includes


  • Original Videos

  • Weekly Articles

  • Photos

  • Vocabulary Charts

  • Historical Maps

  • Historic Quotations and Speeches

  • Timelines

  • Printable Classroom Activities

  • Grading Rubrics for Teachers

  • Completion Certificate



Syllabus


Week 1: Diversity and Discrimination


We live in a wonderfully diverse world full of all types of people! This course begins with the story of Ruby Bridges, an African-American student who attended an all-white school in New Orleans, Louisiana, USA in the year 1960. Through Week 1, student learn about the relationship between diversity and discrimination and begin to look at the history of discrimination in both the United States and South Africa.


Sample Discussion Question: Why do you think some people discriminate against others?



Week 2: Discrimination Long Ago


During Week 2, students travel from South Africa in the 17th Century to the Americas and Australia. Students learn about the Age of Discovery when people from around the world began to interact with one another. As explorers and colonists traveled the world they often fought with the indigenous and aboriginal people they encountered.


Sample Discussion Question: Imagine that you are a Khoi person who has been living at the Cape for hundreds of years. How would you react when Jan van Riebeeck first lands at the Cape of Good Hope? Now switch places and imagine you are Jan van Riebeeck. How would you react when you first meet the Khoi people?



Week 3: Mahatma Gandhi


Who was Mahatma Gandhi and why did people call him “The Great one?” This week, students learn about Gandhi, his fight against discrimination in both South Africa and India, and how he became an inspirational figure in the United States Civil Rights Movement.


Sample Discussion Question: How effective were the different ways Gandhi protested discrimination in South Africa?



Week 4: The Fight for Civil Rights


Martin Luther King Jr. and Nelson Mandela lived on opposite sides of the earth, but fought for a common goal: Equality. This week, students learn about the lives of both Martin Luther King Jr. and Nelson Mandela. Students learn about the Civil Rights Movement in the United States and Nelson Mandela’s fight against the Apartheid in South Africa.


Sample Discussion Question: Who is a person fighting today for civil rights? Compare and contrast this leader with Martin Luther King Jr. and Nelson Mandela.


Week 5: Helen Joseph and Rosa Parks


People are discriminated against based on their race, religion, ethnic group, economic status, and also gender. In Week 5, students learn about women around the world who dedicated their lives to challenging racial inequality.


Sample Discussion Question: Do you think that Helen Joseph and Rosa Parks accomplished their goals considering how people of different race are treated today?



Week 6: Walking to Freedom


How can your students fight discrimination and promote acceptance in their own communities? In the final week of Walking to Freedom, students learn about three individuals fighting today for equality and acceptance.


Sample Discussion Question: This course is titled “Walking to Freedom” because we live in a world where everyone is not treated equally. What are ways you hope to promote equality in your own community?



Reviews

“Bringing communities from around the world together in education can only create a more symbiotic and peaceful existence. Specifically for my students; this is a chance of a lifetime to "travel" somewhere they might never go. My students come from very low income households, and most have never been out of the city, never mind the state or the country. This is a unique experience and I am so glad that PenPal Schools is as passionate about it as I am.” -Jenna, Virginia
